name: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
description: Founded in the 11th century, this property includes the Saint-Sophia Cathedral and the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra monastery complex. The cathedral preserves one of the world's largest ensembles of unique mosaics and frescoes from the first quarter of the 11th century. The monastery became the centre of Christianity in Kyivan Rus in the 11th century.

name: L'viv – the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
description: The city of L'viv, founded in the late Middle Ages, was a flourishing administrative, religious and commercial centre for several centuries. The medieval urban topography has been preserved virtually intact, along with many fine Baroque and later buildings.

name: Struve Geodetic Arc
description: The Struve Arc is a chain of survey triangulations stretching from Hammerfest in Norway to the Black Sea, through ten countries and over 2,820 km. These are points of a survey, carried out between 1816 and 1855 by the astronomer Friedrich Georg Wilhelm Struve, which represented the first accurate measuring of a long segment of a meridian.
transnational: Yes (10 countries: Norway, Sweden, Finland, Russia, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Belarus, Moldova, Ukraine)

name: Residence of Bukovinian and Dalmatian Metropolitans
description: The Residence, built between 1864 and 1882 by Czech architect Josef Hlavka, represents a masterful synergy of architectural styles and building craftsmanship. The property, an outstanding example of 19th-century historicist architecture, also includes a seminary and monastery,園 illustrating the cultural identity of Orthodox Christianity.

name: Ancient City of Tauric Chersonese and its Chora
description: Founded by Dorian Greeks in the 5th century BC on the northern shores of the Black Sea. The site features remains of a polis with urban structures and agricultural lands divided into several hundreds of chora (rectangular plots). The city thrived until the 15th century as a productive wine centre and hub of exchange between Greek, Roman and Byzantine Empires.

name: Wooden Tserkvas of the Carpathian Region in Poland and Ukraine
description: Situated in the eastern fringe of Central Europe, sixteen wooden tserkvas (churches) were built between the 16th and 19th centuries by communities of Orthodox and Greek Catholic faiths. They represent outstanding examples of vernacular religious architecture, which integrates characteristic elements of Byzantine tradition with local traditions.

name: Ancient and Primeval Beech Forests of the Carpathians and Other Regions of Europe
description: This transnational property includes examples of undisturbed temperate forests that demonstrate the postglacial expansion process of European beech. The Ukrainian components are located in the Carpathian Biosphere Reserve and include the Uholka-Shyrokyi Luh and Svydovets areas.
transnational: Yes (18 countries: Albania, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czechia, France, Germany, Italy, North Macedonia, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Switzerland, Ukraine)

name: The Historic Centre of Odesa
description: A cosmopolitan port city on the Black Sea, Odesa reflects the successful fusion of different cultural influences. The city was founded at the end of the 18th century by Catherine II and became an important trading gateway and a cultural melting pot.

name: Historic Centre of Tchernigov 9th-13th centuries
description: Historic urban landscape built between the 9th and 13th centuries. Deeply affected in early months of 2022 war. UNESCO assisting with rehabilitation plan.

name: Complex of the Sudak Fortress Monuments of the 6th-16th c.
description: Medieval defensive architecture highlighting fortifications from the 6th to 16th centuries. Located in occupied Crimea.

name: Kyiv: Saint Sophia Cathedral with Related Monastic Buildings St. Cyril's and St. Andrew's Churches Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
description: Proposed extension of existing World Heritage site to include additional churches of historic and architectural significance.

name: Trading Posts and Fortifications on Genoese Trade Routes from the Mediterranean to the Black Sea
description: Serial transnational nomination documenting Genoese commercial and military architecture along medieval trade routes.

name: Khan's Palace in Bakhchysarai
description: Former residence of Crimean Khans. Located in occupied Crimea.

name: Genoese Fortress in Balaklava
description: Medieval Genoese fortification. Located in occupied Crimea.

name: Kamyanets-Podilsky Historic Centre
description: Historic fortified city with well-preserved medieval and early modern architecture.

name: Sophia of Kyiv – Grand Cultural Capital
description: Proposed expansion focusing on Sophia Cathedral complex and surrounding cultural landscape.

name: Pochayiv Lavra
description: Important Orthodox monastery and pilgrimage site.

name: Medieval Fortresses in the Ukrainian Carpathians
description: System of medieval defensive structures in the Carpathian Mountains.

name: Taras Shevchenko's Grave
description: Memorial site of Ukraine's national poet. Granted UNESCO enhanced protection in 2023.

name: Historic Centres of Kremenets and Zbarazh
description: Historic urban ensembles with significant architectural heritage.

name: Kachanivka Palace and Park Ensemble
description: 18th-19th century palace complex with landscape park.

name: Dormition Cathedral Pochaiv
description: Historic cathedral within Pochayiv Lavra complex.

name: Dniester Canyon
description: Unique natural canyon landscape along the Dniester River.

name: Danube Biosphere Reserve
description: Important wetland ecosystem at the Danube Delta.

name: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
description: Under permanent threat since February 24 2022. Inscribed on List of World Heritage in Danger September 2023. Physical damage in buffer zone. Management plan development stalled. Great Restoration Programme projects suspended due to war.

name: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
description: Continued monitoring and protection efforts. Ongoing threats from armed conflict. Emergency preparedness measures implemented.

name: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
description: Report submitted by State Party. Assessment ongoing.

name: L'viv – the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
description: Inscribed on List of World Heritage in Danger September 2023. Under permanent threat since February 24 2022. Vulnerable to shockwaves from bombing. Multiple protection measures implemented by Ukrainian authorities.

name: L'viv – the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
description: Continued protection and monitoring. Emergency response protocols in place. Training for cultural professionals.

name: L'viv – the Ensemble of the Historic Centre
description: Report submitted by State Party. Assessment ongoing.

name: The Historic Centre of Odesa
description: Inscribed simultaneously on World Heritage List and List of World Heritage in Danger January 25 2023. Significant damage from aerial assaults including July 2023 strikes affecting museums. 52 cultural properties reported damaged of which 47 verified by UNESCO mission.

name: The Historic Centre of Odesa
description: Major attacks November 14-15 2024 damaged historic buildings within property boundaries. Management plan development in progress with UNESCO-ICOMOS support. UNESCO-Japan Funds-in-Trust project providing USD 5.9 million for monitoring and emergency response. UNESCO-Italy project USD 530000 for protective roof on Transfiguration Cathedral.

name: The Historic Centre of Odesa
description: Report submitted by State Party. Ongoing protection and rehabilitation efforts.

name: Ancient City of Tauric Chersonese and its Chora
description: Critical state of conservation of ruins with high dilapidation. Some structures close to collapse. Located in occupied Crimea restricting UNESCO access since 2014.

name: Ancient and Primeval Beech Forests of the Carpathians and Other Regions of Europe
description: Monitoring challenges due to war. No direct conflict damage reported to Ukrainian components as of 2023.

name: Ancient and Primeval Beech Forests of the Carpathians and Other Regions of Europe
description: Continued monitoring within security constraints.

name: Total World Heritage Sites in Ukraine
description: 7 cultural and 1 natural site. 3 sites currently on List of World Heritage in Danger (Kyiv, Lviv, Odesa). 3 sites are transnational.

name: Total Tentative List Sites
description: 16 sites on Tentative List awaiting nomination. Several located in occupied territories.

name: Enhanced Protection List
description: 25 sites added to International List of Cultural Property Under Enhanced Protection in 2023. 2 additional sites (Babyn Yar Memorial and Odesa Literary Museum) added December 2024. Total 27 sites under enhanced protection.

name: Verified Damage
description: UNESCO verified damage to 343 cultural sites as of February 2024: 31 museums 127 religious sites 151 buildings of historical/artistic interest 19 monuments 14 libraries 1 archive. Worst affected regions: Donetsk (88 sites) Kharkiv (56 sites) Odesa (49 sites) Kyiv (39 sites) Luhansk (34 sites).

name: Recovery Costs
description: Estimated cost for recovery and reconstruction of culture and tourism sectors 2024-2033. Increased from USD 6.9 billion in 2023.

name: UNESCO Funding
description: UNESCO raised over USD 66 million from Member States and private sector over 2 years (2022-2024). Japan contributed almost USD 26 million.
